I.  THE ENSUING PROJECT 
 
1.  The  ensuing  project  will  apply  the  financial  intermediation  modality  and  will  provide 
investment finance through the branch network of the Agrarian Credit Corporation JSC (ACC). It 
will  increase the volume  of financial resources  available for  commercially-oriented  livestock 
production and processing.1 It will also provide finance for commercial fodder and feed production. 
Through an attached technical assistance (TA), the project will build the capacity of ACC in 
livestock-related credit policy, product development, procedures, outreach strategy, and in the 
identification, appraisal, and management of livestock sector lending in the broad sense. 
 
2.  The ensuing project will be aligned with the following impacts: competitiveness of agro-
industrial products increased.2 The project will have two outputs: (i) access to finance in the 
livestock sector increased, and (ii) capacity of ACC improved. The outputs will result in the 
following outcome: livestock sector in Kazakhstan improved. The project is estimated to cost 
$166.6 million. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will finance $100.0 million from its ordinary 
capital resources. ACC is expected to contribute 30% of project financing in Tenge equivalent; 
while the subborrowers are assumed to contribute 10% of individual subproject costs in the form 
of equity.  
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
3.  The transaction TA will support the Government of Kazakhstan and ADB make an 
informed decision on the possible investment and preparation of the project.3 In particular, the TA 
will support with the: (i) preparation of the project feasibility study and loan processing, including 
required  due  diligence;  (ii)  relevant  costs  related  to  project  processing  by  ADB  and  the 
government; and (iii) implementation start-up support.  
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
4.  Output 1: Project feasibility study and required due diligence on ACC prepared. This 
will consist of (i) sector and demand analysis; (ii) financial, integrity, governance due diligence of 
the implementing agency, safeguards due diligence and climate risk assessment and mitigation 
strategies; and (iii) support for loan processing document preparation.  
 
5.  Output 2: Attached TA design prepared. This output will prepare the attached TA that 
will strengthen the staff capacities and internal procedures of ACC on credit risk assessment for 
the livestock sector, loan portfolio management, and safeguards compliance. 
 
6.  Output 3: Implementation start-up conducted. This will assist in increasing project 
readiness  and  expediting  project  implementation.  The  output  includes  initial  capacity 
enhancement  activities  of  ACC  for  the  environment  and  social  management  safeguards 
assessment. 
 
7.  The project financial due diligence, including the financial management assessment, and 
 
1  The proposed project is reflected in the Kazakhstan country operations business plan for 2020–2022 for $100.0 
million in 2021. 
2  Government of Kazakhstan. 2017. Program of Agro-industrial Development 2017–2021. Nur-Sultan. 
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 24 April 2020.

2   
environment and social management system to be used by ACC and its branch network in line 
with project requirements will be prepared under ADB’s TA for Developing Rural Financial 
Intermediation. 4  The TA commenced in September 2018, and has been working to  (i) improve 
business  processes  of  ACC,  including    governance,  risk  management  and  business  and 
safeguards procedures; and (ii) improve financial intermediation capacity of ACC. The financial 
due diligence under the TA will include assessing impacts of the current coronavirus disease 
(COVID-19) pandemic on the financial status of ACC. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
8.  The TA is estimated to cost $515,000, of which $500,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The key expenditure items 
are listed in Appendix 1. The Government of Kazakhstan will provide $15,000 equivalent of in-
kind counterpart support in the form of office space for TA consultants, counterpart staff, data and 
information access, and facilitation of liaisons with stakeholders during the feasibility study. The 
government was informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing 
project.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
9.  ADB will administer the TA. ACC will be the lead counterpart agency for the TA. The 
Environment, Agriculture and Natural Resources Division of ADB’s Central and West Asia 
Department will act as the focal point and coordinator of consulting inputs and activities. The 
proposed TA will be implemented over 18 months from July 2020 to December 2021. The 
implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 1.  
 
Table 1: Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects   Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  July 2020–December 2021 
Executing agency  ADB 
Implementing agency  Environment, Agriculture and Natural Resources Division of ADB’s 
Central and West Asia Department

Output 1: Direct  FAO Agreement    $   60,000 
Contracting

Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended 
from time to time).

arrangement upon TA completion 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, FAO = Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations, ICS = individual 
consultant selection, TA = technical assistance. 
Note: The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations will be retained under an agreement for the provision 
of services to undertake the climate change risk assessment and mitigation strategy.  
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
10.  Consulting  Services.  The  TA  will  require  hiring  a  maximum  of  seven  individual 
 
4  ADB. 2018. Technical Assistance to the Republic of Kazakhstan for Developing Rural Financial Intermediation. 
Manila (TA 9650-KAZ, $225,000, completion June 2020).

3 
consultants for the delivery of consultant services.  Individual consultant contracts under outputs 
1 and 2 will be lump-sum contracts; and under output 3, they will be time-based.5 In addition to 
the individual consultants, the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) will 
be engaged to conduct a climate change risk assessment and to develop a climate change risk 
mitigation strategy.6 ADB procurement and policy (2017 as amended from time to time) and 
associated staff instructions and or project administration instructions shall apply to the selection 
of consultants. The expertise and corresponding indicative person-months are in Table 2.7 
Safeguard due diligences will be prepared under a separate TA (para. 7).

E.  Governance 
 
11.  Output 1 of the TA will support the governance and integrity due diligence of the borrower. 
It will provide ADB with a thorough understanding of ACC’s creditworthiness, financial/business 
integrity and sustainability. This will be from a lender and a development partner’s perspective. It 
will identify key areas for enhancing the borrower’s credit, integrity and governance structure. 
 
5  The terms of reference for consultants by consulting service package are accessible from the linked documents in 
Appendix 2. 
6  FAO will be engaged under an agreement that is similar to agreements made with other United Nations agencies 
that do not have an ADB Board-approved memorandum of understanding. 
7  Two positions under separate outputs may be covered by one individual consultant, such as Social Development 
and Gender Specialist under outputs 1 and 3.

4  Appendix 1

LIST OF LINKED DOCUMENTS

1.  Terms of Reference for Consultants

6                        Linked Document 1 
 
 
TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
A.  Project due diligence and preparations 
 
1.  Scope  of work.  Individual  consultants  will  be engaged  to  conduct the  project  due 
diligence, prepare the attached technical assistance report, and support the project’s start-up 
activities. Consultant assignments are short-term in duration and defined in the outline terms of 
reference (TOR) below. For outputs 1 and 2, contracts will be lump sum; and for output 3, 
contracts will be time-based. The expected date of service commencement is July 2020.  
 
2.  Deliverables. Each expert will produce a draft final and final report. All draft final reports 
for outputs 1 and 2 will be submitted within 2 months after mobilization. Final reports will be 
submitted within 2 weeks after receiving comments on the draft final reports from the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) and the government. All reports are expected to be in English, except 
the project administration manual (PAM) and governance due diligence, which must be translated 
into Russian. 
 
3.  Indicative inputs. The schedule of indicative consulting service inputs is in Table 1. The 
outline TOR for each specialist are outlined hereunder. In addition to the experts in the table, the 
Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) of the United Nations will be engaged to conduct a 
climate change risk assessment and develop a climate change risk mitigation strategy.  
 
Table 1: Expected Consulting Service Inputs  
International  National 
Positions 
(person-months)  (person-months) 
Output 1: Project feasibility study and required due diligence on ACC prepared 
Agriculture Specialist / Team Leader    4.0a   
Agriculture Specialist    3.0 
Integrity Due Diligence Specialist  1.0   
Governance Due Diligence Specialist  1.5   
Social Development and Gender Specialist    3.0 
Subtotal (1)  6.5  6.0 
Output 2: Attached technical assistance design prepared 
Agriculture/Finance Sector Specialist  1.0a   
Subtotal (2)  1.0   
Output 3: Implementation start-up conducted

Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
B.  Outline terms of reference 
1. Output 1: Project feasibility study and required due diligence on Agrarian Credit 
Corporation JSC prepared. 
 
4.  Agriculture Specialist and Team Leader (international, intermittent 4.0 person-months).

Linked Document 1                        7 
The international specialist shall have at least a Master’s Degree in agricultural economics or 
similar  field,  with  15  years  relevant  work  experience  in  several  regional  countries.  The 
international specialist will (i) prepare a livestock sector report, including a market assessment 
and credit demand analysis for livestock value chain participants—this will include consideration 
of a credit product design that is appropriate for pandemic situations; (ii) review the reports and 
contributions from each consultant for quality control and consistency with their TOR; (iii) review 
the economic and financial analysis; and (iv) support the preparation of project processing 
documents.  
 
5.  Agriculture Specialist (national, intermittent, 3.0 person-months). The national specialist 
shall have at least a Master’s Degree in agriculture or agricultural economics, with 10 years 
relevant work experience. The national specialist will support the outputs of the international 
specialist. 
 
6.  Integrity Due Diligence Specialist (international, intermittent, 1.0 person-month). The 
specialist shall have at least a Master’s degree in economics, commerce/trade, finance, business 
administration, or a related field, with 15 years relevant work experience in several regional 
countries. The specialist will undertake the necessary investigations to determine the integrity and 
Anti-Money laundering/Combating the Financing of Terrorism (AML/CFT). This will be of the 
Agrarian Credit Corporation JSC (ACC) and its shareholders (including beneficial owners), their 
respective Board of Directors and senior management teams, and material related parties 
(collectively as “Relevant Parties”). It will enable ADB to (i) have a comprehensive and objective 
understanding  of  Relevant  Parties’  current  situation  and  practices  regarding  integrity  and 
AML/CFT, (ii) assess and provide a basis on whether Relevant Parties are acceptable transaction 
counterparties for ADB, and (iii) identify potential conflicts of interest. These should be undertaken 
using desktop research of publicly available information via the internet and databases. 
 
7.  Governance Due Diligence Specialist (international, intermittent,1.5 person-months). 
The specialist shall have at least a Master’s degree in economics, commerce/trade, finance, 
business administration, or a related field, with 15 years relevant work experience in several 
regional countries. The specialist will (i) evaluate the corporate governance arrangements at all 
levels in ACC and identify areas for improvement, and (ii) prepare a capacity development and 
enhancement program. 
 
8.  Social Development and Gender Specialist (national, intermittent, 3.0 person-months). 
The specialist shall have at least a Bachelor’s degree in social sciences, sociology, anthropology, 
or other relevant disciplines for the assignment. (S)he shall have at least 10 years relevant 
experience in social development and gender and development and will have familiarity with ADB 
policies on social safeguards, gender and development, and core labor standards. The specialist 
will (i) review and supplement available market study evaluating the current agri-finance sector. 
This will consider access by women involved in livestock raising to finance products, identify 
constraints/ issues faced, estimate the demand and develop concrete ideas/financial products on 
how to increase financial inclusion of women; (ii) carry out field surveys and focus group 
discussions with women farmers, livestock raisers and relevant community based organizations; 
(iii) conduct gender analysis of the livestock value chain; (iv) profile women and men’s roles in 
the livestock sector as workers, producers, and entrepreneurs. These will identify areas of the 
value where women’s participation is strong and weak and what are the barriers they are facing 
that influence their access or lack of access to financial services; (v) prepare a Gender Action 
Plan (GAP); (vi) prepare the summary poverty reduction and social strategy based on ADB’s 
template; and (vii) provide inputs to the PAM and other investment feasibility study documents in 
compliance with ADB’s social safeguards and gender mainstreaming policies.

8                        Linked Document 1 
 
 
 
9.  Climate Change Assessment and Mitigation Strategy study (by agreement). FAO will 
lead the detailed climate vulnerability and risk assessment to support subproject prioritization and 
design. The study is expected to assess the change and variability of key climate-related 
parameters over the project’s lifetime, to be used as inputs to feasibility studies, among others. 
FAO will identify the uncertainties associated with the projections and provide guidance on how 
the results should be interpreted. They will also prepare greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions 
estimates for the project on a with and without project basis and recommend livestock and land 
management strategies for GHG mitigation. 
 
b. Output 2: Attached technical assistance design prepared 
 
10.  Agriculture/Finance Sector Specialist (international, intermittent, 1.0 person-month). 
The international specialist shall have at least a Master’s degree in agriculture or agricultural 
economics, with 15 years relevant work experience in several regional countries. The specialist 
will prepare (including a cost estimate) an “attached technical assistance” which supports the 
strengthening of ACC in credit risk assessment, loan portfolio management, staff capacities and 
internal procedures. 
 
c. Output 3: Implementation start-up conducted 
 
11.  Project Implementation Specialists (international, intermittent, 3.0 person-months and 
national, intermittent, 3.0 person-months). The international specialist shall have at least a 
Master’s degree in agriculture, agricultural economics or finance or related field, with 15 years 
relevant work experience in several regional countries. The national specialist shall have at least 
a Master’s degree in agriculture or agricultural economics or finance or related filed with 10 years 
relevant work experience The specialists shall have familiarity with ADB reporting, due diligence, 
and disbursement guidelines and practices. Following loan approval, the specialists will work with 
ACC to ensure processes are followed to ensure a smooth and accelerated start-up. 
 
12.  Social  Development  and  Gender  Specialist  (national,  4.0  person-months).  The 
specialist shall have at least a Bachelor’s degree in social sciences, sociology, anthropology, 
gender studies agriculture and rural development or other relevant disciplines for the assignment. 
(S)he shall have at least 10 years relevant experience in social development and/or gender and 
development and will have familiarity with ADB policies on social safeguards, gender and 
development, and core labor standards. Working with ACC, the consultant will (i) provide staff 
training for the implementation of the social sector component of the environmental and social 
management system (ESMS); (ii) ensure implementation of the gender action plans; and (iii) 
develop a program to raise public awareness of financial products among rural women. 
 
13.  Environment Specialist (national, 4.0 person-months). The specialist shall have at least 
a Bachelor’s degree in environmental studies, or other relevant disciplines for the assignment. 
Working  with  ACC,  the  consultant  will  provide  staff  training  for  the  implementation  of  the 
environment sector component of the ESMS.
